# Introduction

```{r}
f_ash <- function(c0, ct) {
  1 - c0/ct
}

f_ash_ct <- function(c0, gamma) {
  c0 / (1 - gamma)
}

d_ash <-
  tidyr::expand_grid(
    c0 = c(0.25, 1.03)/100,
    c0_assumed = c(0.25, 1.03)/100,
    gamma = 
      c(0, 0.1, 0.5, seq(0, 0.999, length.out = 20)) |>
      unique()
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    ct = f_ash_ct(c0 = c0, gamma = gamma),
    gamma_ash = f_ash(c0 = c0_assumed, ct = ct),
    gamma_ash =
      dplyr::case_when(
        gamma_ash < 0 ~ 0,
        TRUE ~ gamma_ash
      ),
    gamma_error = gamma - gamma_ash
  )
```

Peatland mass and carbon balance are the net result of net primary production (NPP) as mass input and of decomposition as mass output. If we could accurately describe how decomposition is controlled by environmental conditions, we could improve reconstructions of past and predictions of future peatland dynamics.  
Theory and modeling studies suggest a complex feedback between decomposition and net peat accumulation [@Bauer.2004; @Belyea.2006; @Mahdiyasa.2022]. As a direct effect, decomposition decreases net peat accumulation because mass is lost from the system, but as an indirect effect, this mass loss decreases peat height, porosity, and hydraulic conductivity, which can increase surface wetness and therefore may increase litter production and decrease decomposition over longer time periods. Under some conditions, more decomposition can therefore increase future net peat accumulation [e.g., @Quillet.2013].  
When analyzing decomposition processes, an important quantity is the degree of decomposition ($\gamma$), the fraction of initial mass that was lost due to decomposition. It is directly measured in litterbag experiments and allows to estimate decomposition rates and how they are controlled by environmental conditions. Peatland models use these estimates to simulate decomposition in peatlands for decades to millenia [e.g., @Frolking.2010]. However, litterbag experiments only cover short time periods which leads to imprecise estimates for parameters that take effect only over longer time periods, such as the slow-down of decomposition due to increasing recalcitrance of the material left behind [@Frolking.2001]. Estimates for $\gamma$ of peat are also useful to disentangle peat accumulation scenarios: an unfortunate consequence of the ecohydrological feedback is that both small and large water table depths (WTD) may lead to very similar peat heights and masses, two variables often used to test peatland models, but litter production, decomposition losses, the net mass balance, and the peat degree of decomposition differ between these contrasting scenarios [@Ramirez.2023]. For this reason, estimates of $\gamma$ for peat samples would be useful to distinguish between these conditions and to obtain more accurate estimates for processes rates [@Ramirez.2023].   
One of the currently most promising methods to estimate $\gamma$ is the ash residue method ($\gamma_\text{ARM}$) [e.g., @Leifeld.2011a; @Leifeld.2011]. This approach assumes that the total mass of ash or some other compound, for example titanium (Ti), does not change during decomposition because the compound is inert. Because of decomposition mass losses of the organic matter, the concentration of ash increases and the degree of decomposition is therefore proportional to the ratio of the ash concentration in the undecomposed sample to the ash concentration in the decomposed sample ($\gamma(t) = \gamma_\text{ARM}(t) = 1 - \frac{c_\text{ash}(t_0)}{c_\text{ash}(t)}$). The limitation of this method is that currently no reliable method exists to estimate the initial ash or Ti concentration of a peat sample [@Leifeld.2011; @Kruger.2016]. For example, for the ombrotrophic peat cores in @Kruger.2016, $c_\text{ash}(t_0)$ may range between `r d_ash |> dplyr::pull(c0) |> magrittr::divide_by(100) |> range() |> units::set_units(g/g) |> units::set_units(mg/g) |> units::drop_units() |> knitr::combine_words(and = " to at least ")` mg g$^{-1}$ for many peat layers; this leads to no errors when only ash is left ($\gamma = 1$), but errors quickly increase with decreasing $\gamma$: for $\gamma = 0.5$, the error is up to `r d_ash |> dplyr::filter(gamma == 0.5) |> dplyr::pull(gamma_error) |> abs() |> max() |> magrittr::multiply_by(100) |> round(0)`%, for $\gamma = 0.1$, the error is up to `r d_ash |> dplyr::filter(gamma == 0.1) |> dplyr::pull(gamma_error) |> abs() |> max() |> magrittr::multiply_by(100) |> round(0)`%. Thus, $\gamma_\text{ARM}$ has comparatively large errors, especially for less decomposed peat, and these errors make it difficult to use $\gamma_\text{ARM}$ in peatland models. To our knowledge, no other approach to estimate the degree of decomposition of peat on an absolute scale exists.  
Other approaches only estimate relative differences in the degree of decomposition between samples [@Biester.2014], with peat properties that are assumed to be correlated with the degree of decomposition (decomposition indicators). A problem in the application of decomposition indicators we know of is that, the exact relation to the degree of decomposition (monotonous, linear, nonlinear, etc.) is unknown, confounding variables are known to weaken or to reverse the relation to the degree of decomposition, or worse, potential confounders are unknown, and values of the decomposition indicators may be highly variable already for undecomposed peat because of differences in litter chemistry. For example, the C/N ratio is different for undecomposed litter of different species [e.g., @Biester.2014; @Scheffer.2001; @Limpens.2003] and therefore vegetation shifts in a peat core can reverse the relation between the C/N ratio and the degree of decomposition; bulk density depends in a complex way on compaction processes and structural properties of organic matter from different vegetation species [e.g., @Mahdiyasa.2022] and also depends on mineral contents; humification indices fail when the fraction of minerals is too high [e.g., @Broder.2012] or changes in amide abundances are not caused by decomposition but for example vegetation shifts [@Stuart.2004; @Teickner.2022f]. Such error sources are difficult to take into account in peatland models and it would therefore be more promising to develop a decomposition indicator that estimates $\gamma$ on an absolute scale. As a first step, existing decomposition indicators could be related to $\gamma$ measured in litterbag experiments to better understand how they relate to $\gamma$, but such tests are for example not included in recent reviews of decomposition indicators [@Biester.2014; @Zaccone.2018]. In summary, it is poorly understood how much decomposition indicators vary for undecomposed litter between species and how decomposition indicators relate to $\gamma$.  
To address the problems to measure $\gamma$, we suggest to first define properties of an ideal decomposition indicator and then to develop a decomposition indicator that has these properties. An ideal decomposition indicator is linearly related to the degree of decomposition, well tested against litterbag data, does not confound differences in litter chemistry of undecomposed litter with decomposition, and is robust against other potential confounding factors, in particular mineral contents. A model that predicts $\gamma$ measured from litterbag experiments and undecomposed litter with mid infrared spectra (MIRS) may fulfill these requirements because MIRS from litterbag experiments contain information about the relative abundance and interactions of many molecular structures [@Stuart.2004] which change in abundance during decomposition and differ between plant species [e.g., @Arsenault.2024a; @Chapman.2001; @Cocozza.2003; @Tfaily.2014]. In contrast to other decomposition indicators that use simple formulas and no training data, such as C/N or humification indices, using a statistical model and undecomposed litter from various species as reference should avoid confounding differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter with differences in chemistry due to decomposition. In contrast to $\gamma_\text{ARM}$, no knowledge of initial states is required because $\gamma$ is predicted only with information from the decomposed sample. Previous studies used MIRS to predict various peat properties [e.g., @Artz.2008; @Chapman.2001], but, to our knowledge, not the degree of decomposition. It would therefore be useful to develop a model that predicts $\gamma$ measured in litterbag experiments from MIRS ($\gamma_\text{MIRS}$).  
An error source that received surprisingly little attention in the literature is the underestimation of $\gamma$ for samples with multiple components by many decomposition indicators except for those similar to $\gamma_\text{ARM}$. With $\gamma_\text{ARM}$, it is possible to estimate $\gamma$ of a peat sample consisting of multiple components (multi-component system) in exactly the same way as $\gamma$ for an individual component because each component contributes some ash mass that is always the same, no matter how decomposed the component is or how much other components contribute to the peat sample; the signal changes linearly when new components are added to the system. In contrast, other decomposition indicators (e.g. C/N, bulk density) measure a signal that depends on the degree of decomposition and therefore change non-linearly when a new component is added to the system. As a consequence, components with larger degree of decomposition contribute less to the measured signal of the system relative to their initial mass than components with smaller degree of decomposition: $\gamma$ will be underestimated. This is also the case for $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ because more decomposed components contribute less to the MIRS signal relative to their initial mass than less decomposed components.<!--Thus, while $\gamma$ of a multi-component system is a weighted average of the degree of decomposition of its components, where weights are the initial masses of the components, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ of a multi-component system is a weighted average of the degree of decomposition of its components, where weights are the masses of the components at the time of sampling. It is important to note that this limitation is not exclusive to $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$, but applies to all decomposition indicators that aim to measure $\gamma$ on an absolute scale or interval scale and do not have the property of $\gamma_\text{ARM}$ that the measured signal (the mass of ash) changes linearly when new components are added to a sample.--> Reviews on peat decomposition indicators [@Biester.2014; @Zaccone.2018] do no mention this bias.  
There are two options to avoid this bias and estimate $\gamma$ for multi-component systems with $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ or other decomposition indicators other than $\gamma_\text{ARM}$: Firstly, if it is possible to measure $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ and the mass of each component and if $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is a good estimate for $\gamma$ for each component, then one can estimate the initial mass of each component and compute an unbiased estimate for $\gamma$. Secondly, one can estimate $\gamma$ with $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ measured on the bulk sample for conditions where an error analysis indicates only small effect of the bias; this requires to identify conditions under which the bias is small.  
Even when the bias of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ for a multi-component system is not corrected, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is still a useful decomposition indicator. It is useful to improve peatland models because peatland models can predict the degree of decomposition weighted by the components masses and this biased degree of decomposition is directly comparable to $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$. A component-specific analysis offers even more opportunities for peatland models. In contrast, existing approaches, for instance using the C/N ratio [e.g., @Ramirez.2023], may have larger errors because, in addition to the bias, which is also a limitation of C/N, and C dynamics, also N dynamics have to be modeled for different plant functional types. $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is also useful in peat core analyses: Without any correction, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is the largest possible degree of decomposition of the least decomposed component (since an average cannot be larger than all individual values) and the smallest possible degree of decomposition of the most decomposed component (since an average cannot be smaller than all individual values). Also here, a component-specific offers many more possibilities.  
Thus, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ has potential advantages compared to existing decomposition indicators that are summarized in Tab. \@ref(tab:dd-table-1). We expect that an analysis of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ for each component of a peat sample (component-specific analysis) is particularly useful because this offers the opportunity to correct the bias and provides much more information useful to improve peatland models. Moreover, a component-specific analysis also allows to reconstruct past NPP without a process model and to use peat samples to analyze decomposition processes in the same way as litterbag experiments, but over long time scales.

These advantages depend on how accurate predictions of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ for individual components (litter types) will be. It is therefore relevant to develop and evaluate a prediction model for $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ and analyze in more detail how estimates for $\gamma$ by $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ or other decomposition indicators are biased in multi-component systems. Specifically, our study has the following aims:

1. We develop and evaluate models to predict the degree of decomposition of individual components of a peat sample from MIRS with data from available litterbag experiments and undecomposed litter samples.

2. We explore how well other commonly used decomposition indicators relate to the degree of decomposition as measured in litter samples and how much they confound differences in litter properties of undecomposed litter with decomposition mass losses.

3. We estimate how much $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ and the other decomposition indicators underestimate $\gamma$ for peat samples with two or more components and under what conditions $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is a good approximation for $\gamma$ and can be used to reconstruct past NPP with small error. 

4. Based on this analysis, we estimate $\gamma$ and reconstruct the NPP of *Sphagnum* species in peat samples from two peat cores using $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$. In addition, we discuss how $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ may be useful to analyze long-term peat decomposition.

$$

For $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&& \gamma_\text{MIRS}(t) &=& \sum_i^n \left( \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t) \frac{m_i(t)}{m(t)} \right)\\
&\iff& 1 - \frac{m(t)}{m(t_0)} &=&  1 - \frac{\sum_i^n \left( \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t) m_i(t) \right)}{m(t_0) \gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)}\\
&\iff& \gamma(t) &=&  1 - \frac{(1 - \gamma(t)) \sum_i^n \left( \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t) m_i(t) \right)}{m(t) \gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)}\\
&\iff& \gamma(t) &=&  1 - \frac{\sum_i^n \left( \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t) m_i(t) \right)}{m(t) \gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)} + \frac{\gamma(t) \sum_i^n \left( \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t) m_i(t) \right)}{m(t) \gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)}\\
\end{aligned}
$$





A general formula for the value of a decomposition indicator $r$ for component $i$ at time $t$ is:

\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
r_i(t) &=& (r_i(t_0) + f_i(\gamma_i(t))) \beta_{1,i} \frac{m_i(t)}{m_i(t_0)}\\ 
&=& (r_i(t_0) + f_i(\gamma_i(t))) \beta_{1,i} (1 - \gamma_i(t)),
\end{aligned}
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-1)
\end{equation}

where $r_i(t_0)$ is the value of the decomposition indicator for the undecomposed component, $\gamma_i(t)$ is the degree of decomposition of the component at time $t$, $m_i(t)$ is the mass of the component at time $t$, $m_i(t_0)$ is the mass of the undecomposed component, $\frac{m_i(t)}{m_i(t_0)}$ is the remaining fraction of the initial mass of the component, $\beta_{1,i}$ defines how $r_i$ depends on the fraction of initial mass remaining, and $f_i(\gamma_i(t))$ is a function that describes how $r_i$ depends on the degree of decomposition. 

For the ash residue method and an ideal decomposition indicator (such as the MIRS-predicted degree of decomposition when the model has small prediction errors), $f(\gamma_i(t)) = \beta_{2,i} \gamma_i(t)$, where $\beta_{2,i}$ is some constant. \end{aligned}
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-2)
\end{equation}

where $r_{\text{ideal},i}(t) = \gamma_i(t)$, since $r_{\text{ideal},i}(t)$ is the ideal decomposition indicator. The degree of decomposition of a peat sample consisting of $n$ components is the weighted average of the degree of decomposition of each component, where weights are the initial masses of the components:

For the ash residue method, $r_i(t)$ is the mass of ash of component $i$, and for any $i$, $\beta_{2,i} = 0$, $\beta_1 = \frac{1}{(1 - \gamma_i(t))}$, and $r_i(t) = r_i(t_0)$. For an ideal decomposition indicator, for any $i$, $r_i(t) = \gamma_i(t)$, $r_i(t_0) = \gamma_i(t_0) = 0$, $\beta_{2,i} = 1$, and $\beta_1 = \frac{1}{(1 - \gamma_i(t))}$ for all $t \ge t_0$.









 

\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
&& r_{\text{ash},i}(t) &=& r_{\text{ash},i}(t_0)\\
&\iff& m_i(t) c_{\text{ash},i}(t) &=& m_i(t_0) c_{\text{ash},i}(t_0)\\
&\iff& \gamma(t) &=& 1 - \frac{m_i(t)}{m_i(t_0)} = 1 - \frac{c_{\text{ash},i}(t_0)}{c_{\text{ash},i}(t)},
\end{aligned}
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-2)
\end{equation}

which shows the dependence on the initial ash concentration, $c_{\text{ash},i}(t_0)$. For an ideal decomposition indicator, $r_i(t) = \gamma_i(t)$, $r_i(t_0) = \gamma_i(t_0) = 0$, $\beta_2 = 1$, and $\beta_1 = \frac{1}{(1 - \gamma_i(t))}$ for all $t \ge t_0$:

\begin{equation}
r_{\text{ideal},i}(t) = \gamma_i(t)
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-3)
\end{equation}

When we predict $r_i(t) = \gamma_i(t)$ with a spectral model from MIRS ($r_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)$), then $\beta_1 = \frac{1}{(1 - \gamma_i(t))}$ because MIRS are measured with a defined mass of the sample and are normalized in a standardized way during spectral preprocessing and therefore $r_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)$ is independent of how much of the initial mass is left. Therefore:

\begin{equation}
r_{\text{MIRS},i}(t) = (r_{\text{MIRS},i}(t_0) + f_{\text{MIRS},i}(\gamma_i(t)))
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-4)
\end{equation}

When we fit a spectral prediction model to litterbag data for component $i$ and this model is a good approximation for the measured degree of decomposition, then $f_{\text{MIRS},i}(\gamma_i(t))$ has the same form as for the ideal decomposition indicator and therefore $r_{\text{MIRS},i}(t) = \gamma_i(t)$.

The degree of decomposition of a peat sample consisting of $n$ components is the initial mass-weighted average of the degree of decomposition of each component:

\begin{equation}
\gamma(t) = \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t_0) \gamma_i(t_0)}{\sum_i^n m_i(t_0)}
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-5)
\end{equation}

For the ash residue method, this is:

\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
\gamma(t) &=& \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t_0) \left(1 - \frac{c_{\text{ash},i}(t_0)}{c_{\text{ash},i}(t)} \right)}{\sum_i^n m_i(t_0)}\\
&=& \frac{\sum_i^n \left(m_i(t_0) - \frac{r_{\text{ash},i}(t_0)}{c_{\text{ash},i}(t)} \right)}{\sum_i^n m_i(t_0)}\\
&=& 1 - \frac{\sum_i^n \frac{r_{\text{ash},i}(t_0)}{c_{\text{ash},i}(t)}}{m(t_0)}\\
&=& 1 - \frac{c_\text{ash}(t_0)}{c_\text{ash}(t)},\\
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-6)
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}

and therefore the method is unbiased for multi-component systems. For MIRS predicted degree of decomposition, the formula is:

\begin{equation}
\gamma(t) = \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t_0) \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)}{\sum_i^n m_i(t_0)},
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-7)
\end{equation}

and it is impossible to compute $\gamma(t)$ without $m_i(t_0)$ (or $m_i(t)$ or $\gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)$, from which $m_i(t_0)$ can be computed). The degree of decomposition of the system estimated from MIRS ($\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$) is the mass-weighted average of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ of the individual components:

\begin{equation}
\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t) = \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t) \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)}{\sum_i^n m_i(t)} = \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t) \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)}{m(t_0) (1 - \gamma(t))} 
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-8)
\end{equation}





It is less clear and much more difficult to test whether a MIRS-predicted $\gamma$ ($\gamma_\text{MIRS}$), or other decomposition indicators that rely on organic matter properties, fulfill these properties. The MIRS absorbance caused by a particular molecular structure is proportional to the amount of the molecular structure contained in the components of the sample. As a component gets decomposed, its contribution to the absorbance caused by the molecular structure also decreases, unless the molecular structure gets enriched more relative to the overall mass loss of the component. This may result in $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ underestimating $\gamma$ in multi-component systems. Testing this confounder can be done either by mixing real litterbag samples, measuring MIRS, and then comparing $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ to $\gamma$ calculated from the litterbag experiment, or by assuming that MIRS are scaled relative to sample masses, computing mixture spectra of separate litterbag samples, and then comparing $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ to $\gamma$ calculated from the litterbag experiment. Here, we will use the second approach since it does not require additional litterbag experiments. These estimates can be compared to theoretical calculations where $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is a mass-weighted average of $\gamma$ of the individual components. 




This error in $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is also relevant when reconstructing past net primary production (NPP) from masses of peat layers. Reconstructing past NPP is required to understand past peatland dynamics and compare contemporary process rates to past conditions. Apart from process models and the ash residue method (or approaches using other decomposition indicators), no other method exists to reconstruct past NPP. The initial mass of a peat sample can be computed from its mass at sampling ($m(t)$) and its degree of decomposition at the same time ($\gamma(t)$) as $\frac{m(t)}{1 - \gamma(t)}$. When the sample only consists of aboveground parts, the reconstructed initial mass is the aboveground NPP during the period the plants that formed the sample grew. Therefore, if $\gamma$ can be estimated accurately, it would also be possible to reconstruct past NPP or initial sample masses. It would be useful to reconstruct the initial mass of the sample using $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ instead of $\gamma(t)$, but this is a naive approach because $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ may underestimate $\gamma(t)$, as described above. Conditions under which $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ can be used to reconstruct past NPP with small errors or under which the errors can be avoided, will need to be elaborated.-->

A naive reconstruction of past NPP is the result of division of the mass of a peat layer by the fraction of initial mass remaining (one minus the degree of decomposition). <!--Here, we propose a new decomposition indicator based on mid infrared spectra that, in contrast to available decomposition indicators, aims to directly measure the degree of decomposition, is relatively easy to measure, and may be more robust to confounding factors. The idea is to predict the degree of decomposition measured in available litterbag experiments from mid infrared spectra. Molecular bonds absorb infrared radiation at different wavelengths and the fraction of radiation absorbed depends on the abundance of the molecular structure containing the bond and the bonds' electronegativity [@Stuart.2004]. Therefore, MIRS from litterbag experiments contain semi-quantitative information about the relative abundance of molecular structures and their interactions in peat and allow to measure how these change during decomposition. This information can be extrapolated to peat samples. Previous studies used MIRS to predict various peat properties, but, to our knowledge, not the degree of decomposition. Our first aim is to develop and evaluate a model to predict the degree of decomposition from MIRS based on data from available litterbag experiments and undecomposed litter samples.

To this end, we use available data from litterbag experiments and litter with MIRS measured on undecomposed and decomposed litter to compute a prediction model. Available litterbag data include *Sphagnum capillifolium*, *Typha latifolia*, and *Phragmites australis*, and therefore only species with comparatively small aromatic contents. Inclusion of undecomposed litter samples from shrubs and trees avoids too high degree of decomposition estimates in undecomposed peat samples with large aromatic contents. To estimate sensible prediction errors, we use beta regression models and Bayesian inference. To avoid overfitting, we use regularizing horseshoe priors [---todo: check name of prior]. We evaluate our model quantitatively by 10-fold cross-validation (CV) to estimate prediction accuracy on new samples similar to the training data, and qualitatively by analyzing residual patterns, sensitivity to gradual addition of minerals and very decomposed peat, and peat profiles featuring drainage layers on top of undecomposed peat followed by peat formed since rewetting.-->

<!--Since the aim is to apply the model also to new peat samples, but peat samples with known degree of decomposition are not available, a quantitative evaluation is impossible. The suggested decomposition indicator should estimate a larger degree of decomposition for drained parts or preceding drier conditions [---todo: check Morris paper] and a smaller degree of decomposition at the top and in peat formed since rewetting.

Minerals can absorb infrared radiation and the resulting peaks dominate over peaks caused by organic matter when mineral contents are too large. It is known that large mineral contents bias humification indices because they assume a large intensity at 1090 cm$^{-1}$ indicates a large content of carbohydrates, even though it can also indicate a large content of silica minerals [---todo:ref]. # Methods

## Training data

To estimate and test prediction models, we used the following litterbag data: *Sphagnum capillifolium* (whole plant) and *Typha latifolia* (leaves) samples incubated in bog peat and pools (oxic and anoxic conditions) in Canada [@Arsenault.2024a], and *Phragmites australis* (leaves and rhizomes) grown under different nutrient availability and incubated under anoxic conditions in peat with different nutrient availability [@Reuter.2019; @Reuter.2019a; @Reuter.2020]. In addition, we used undecomposed litter samples (some collected under natural conditions, some grown in laboratory experiments with different nutrient availability) of `r dd_data_model |> dplyr::filter(dd_dataset_label == "pmird_undecomposed_litter") |> dplyr::mutate(taxon_rank_value = paste0("*", taxon_rank_value, "*")) |> dplyr::pull(taxon_rank_value) |> unique() |> sort() |> knitr::combine_words()` from the pmird database [@Teickner.2025c; `r dd_citations_data$pmird_undecomposed_litter_citations |> dplyr::mutate(BIBTEXKEY = paste0("@", BIBTEXKEY)) |> dplyr::arrange(YEAR) |> dplyr::pull(BIBTEXKEY) |> unique() |> paste(collapse = "; ")`] where the taxon was known (i.e., no bulk vegetation samples from the top of cores). For undecomposed litter samples, we assumed a degree of decomposition of 0 %. In total, `r nrow(dd_data_model)` litter samples were available for model training. All MIRS used in this study are measured in transmission mode on Fourier-transform infrared spectrometers (FTIR) as milled samples mixed with potassium bromide into transparent pellets. MIRS were measured on different devices (`r dd_data_model |> dplyr::mutate(measurement_device_first_30char_duplciated = measurement_device |> stringr::str_sub(start = 1L, end = 30L) |> duplicated()) |> dplyr::filter(! measurement_device_first_30char_duplciated & ! is.na(measurement_device)) |> dplyr::pull(measurement_device) |> knitr::combine_words()`).    

## Peat data

Data from peat profiles to evaluate the models qualitatively were derived from the pmird database [`r dd_citations_data$dd_data_pmird_peat_cores_citations |> dplyr::mutate(BIBTEXKEY = paste0("@", BIBTEXKEY)) |> dplyr::arrange(YEAR) |> dplyr::pull(BIBTEXKEY) |> unique() |> paste(collapse = "; ")`]. These are: Two cores from the peatland Venner Moor, a core from the peatland Odersprungmoor (OD2) [@Galka.2022a], a core from the peatland Martinskapelle (MK1) [@Galka.2022], a core from the peatland Mohoş (MH1) [@Diaconu.2020], and three cores from Patagonian peatlands (PBR 1, Sky 1, Sky 2) [@Broder.2012]. Cores from @Galka.2022a, @Galka.2022, and @Diaconu.2020 have macrofossils and can therefore be used to define components of peat samples as litter types (under the assumption that litter from the same species has the same decomposition rate and therefore a similar degree of decomposition as measured by our models).

## Prediction model development

We used beta regression models to predict the degree of decomposition (the fraction of initial mass lost) from intensities in preprocessed MIRS. To harmonize the spectra, we interpolated them to unit wavenumber resolution and clipped them to the range 600 to 4000 cm$^{-1}$. Depending on the variable and properties of the MIRS, different preprocessing steps may maximize predictive performance. Therefore, we computed models with different preprocessing steps in addition to the harmonization: (1) Baseline correction, signal normal variate (SNV) (model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)`), (2) First derivative spectra, SNV (model `r dd_model_names(2, dd_model_info)`), (3) Second derivative spectra, SNV (model `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)`). After that, spectra were binned (bin width 10 cm$^{-1}$) to reduce the number of predictors and reduce correlation between predictors, and all predictors were $z$-transformed across all spectra. All preprocessing steps were performed with the ir package [@Teickner.2022i]. Baseline correction was done with an automated convex hull procedure [@Beleites.2021]. Spectra of some undecomposed litter samples have artefacts from CO$_2$, as indicated by peaks around 2360 cm$^{-1}$ [@Wallace.1997a]. To avoid that these peaks have an effect on the normalization or models, we linearly interpolated intensities between 2300 and 2380 cm$^{-1}$ and excluded variables from this range from the models. CO$_2$ also produces peaks around 670 cm$^{-1}$ and 3580 to 3780 cm$^{-1}$, but we did not correct these because they overlap with peaks from organic matter and are smaller than the peaks between 2300 and 2380 cm$^{-1}$ [@Wallace.1997a].   
Beta regression models were computed with brms [@Burkner.2018], using a logit link function, assuming a constant shape parameter, using a normal prior for the intercept, and regularized horseshoe priors [@Piironen.2017a; @Piironen.2017b] for the slopes (for each predictor variable). The regularized horseshoe prior shrinks coefficients to zero except where they are strongly related to the response variable, conditional on other predictors. To reduce overfitting, we defined a large amount of shrinkage, by assuming that `r unique(dd_model_info$par_ratio) * nrow(dd_model_info$x[[1]]$spectra[[1]] )` of the `r dd_model_info$x[[1]]$spectra[[1]] |> nrow()` predictor variables have non-zero coefficients [@Piironen.2017b]. Bayesian inference was done using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling with Stan [@StanDevelopmentTeam.2021a], using `r dd_stan_1_mcmc_settings$warmup` warmup iterations and `r dd_stan_1_mcmc_settings$iter - dd_stan_1_mcmc_settings$warmup` sampling iterations. Across all models, the maximum Monte Carlo standard error [@Vehtari.2021] for the degree of decomposition predicted for the training data and all analyzed peat samples was `r dd_stan_1_fit_mcse |> dplyr::filter(variable == "dd_mcse_mean") |> dplyr::pull(max) |> max() |> magrittr::multiply_by(100) |> round(1)`% for the mean, `r dd_stan_1_fit_mcse |> dplyr::filter(variable == "dd_mcse_sd") |> dplyr::pull(max) |> max() |> magrittr::multiply_by(100) |> round(1)`% (for standard deviations), and `r dd_stan_1_fit_mcse |> dplyr::filter(variable %in% c("dd_mcse_lower", "dd_mcse_upper")) |> dplyr::pull(max) |> max() |> magrittr::multiply_by(100) |> round(1)`% (for lower and upper 95% prediction interval boundaries). No model had divergent transitions and the largest rank-normalized $\hat{R}$ for model parameters was `r dd_stan_1_fit_rhat |> dplyr::pull(rhat) |> max() |> round(2)`, indicating convergence of the chains [@Vehtari.2021].

## Model evaluation

We estimated the predictive accuracy of the models with 10-fold cross-validation (CV). CV folds were defined in two ways to evaluate predictive performance for two scenarios. In the first scenario, we used stratified CV, where each observation is assigned to a categorical variable and observations are split into the 10 folds while approximately preserving relative category frequencies. Each observation was assigned to a category based on the study, species, and, for samples from @Reuter.2019, the site where the litter was grown (to balance occurrence of rhizome litter with different nutrient contents). This procedure approximates a test of the models with samples similar to the training data, as far as this is possible with our small and heterogeneous dataset. In the second scenario, we used grouped CV, where each observation is assigned to a categorical variable and observations for the same categorical variable all are assigned to the same fold. The categorical variable was the same as for the stratified CV. This estimates predictive performance for novel litter types that are not part of the training data, for example the only litterbag data with *Sphagnum* litter is from @Arsenault.2024a, and therefore in this scenario a model not trained on decomposed *Sphagnum* litter predicts the degree of decomposition for decomposed *Sphagnum* litter. The procedure also implies that some folds only contain undecomposed litter because there are fewer categories for litterbag data than CV-folds. The purpose of this second scenario is to test model robustness for novel litter types and therefore to identify limitations of application of a first version of the models trained on few distinct litter types.   
To compare models, we used the expected log predictive density (ELPD) computed on observations held out during CV. Model evaluation was performed with the loo package [@Vehtari.2019]. Following rules of thumb [@Sivula.2022], we assumed models to have equivalent predictive performance (according to the capability of our evaluation) when the difference of their ELPD ($\Delta$ELPD) is smaller than 4, and otherwise when $\Delta$ELPD is larger than two times its standard error (using normal approximation for $\Delta$ELPD). To give an easier to interpret performance metric, we also computed the root mean square error (RMSE).  
We analyzed what fraction of the analyzed peat samples is within the prediction domain of the models. The prediction domain of a model (based on @Wadoux.2021, defined in @Teickner.2023) is the range of the predictor variables covered by the training data. A sample is within the prediction domain if its preprocessed spectrum is within the range for each predictor variable, otherwise it is outside the prediction domain. If a sample is outside the prediction domain, it has spectral properties that cannot be interpolated from the training data and therefore the model extrapolates when making predictions for the spectra. In particular with models that overfit, this may lead to larger prediction errors than fitting errors for the training data.  
We analyzed whether residuals are related to the nitrogen content as proxy for proteins because it is known that protein content differs between species and increases during decomposition [@Reuter.2020; @Scheffer.2001; @Limpens.2003; @Biester.2014], and that proteins, despite their comparatively small amount in peat, are a main control of the height and shape of peaks that are also caused by aromatics [@Stuart.2004]. Thus, if one considers that the training data contains decomposed litter only from three species, the fit of the models may be confounded by proteins and this may bias predictions, especially under extrapolation.  
The impacts of minerals on the estimated degree of decomposition was evaluated by adding a scaled version of a spectrum of a peat sample from the pmird database [@Drollinger.2019; @Drollinger.2020] with large mineral content (`r dd_data_pmird_mineral |> dplyr::mutate(res = (1 - loss_on_ignition)) |> dplyr::pull(res) |> round(2)` g g$^{-1}$, computed from loss on ignition; based on the mid infrared spectrum (Fig. \@ref(si-fig:dd-plot-16)), many of them are silicates [@Stuart.2004; @Parikh.2014]) to selected spectra from the training data from different taxa and with different degree of decomposition. A range of scaling factors from absence of silicates to a clear dominance of silicates was chosen and we predicted the degree of decomposition for each spectrum created this way. For the same samples from the training data, we evaluated the impact of adding increasing amounts of a very decomposed sample (based on HI$_{1630/1090}$, peat structure, C content, and degree of decomposition predicted by all models).  
Finally, we evaluated qualitative behavior of the models for two peat cores from the peatland Venner Moor [@Teickner.2025c] and three peat cores from Patagonian peatlands [@Broder.2012]. The Venner Moor is a former bog that was used for small-scale peat extraction, drained in 1895 for channel constructions and partly rewetted since the 1970's [@Wilkens.1955; @NaturschutzzentrumKreisCoesfeldeV.2017]. The first core was taken in the part of the peatland that was used for peat extraction and rewetted; here, predictions should indicate a small degree of decomposition for peat formed after rewetting and a sharp transition to the remaining peat that was decomposed during drainage. The second core was taken up to the mineral base in an area without peat extraction that was not rewetted and is overgrown by trees; here, predictions should indicate a small degree of decomposition for the top 5 cm where undecomposed leaves and *Sphagnum* grow, a large degree of decomposition for the part above the water table level, and a smaller degree of decomposition for the, based on C/N, HI$_{1630/1090}$, and photographs, undecomposed water saturated lower part (except for the bottom sections). The Patagonian cores feature ash layers and therefore allow to explore how the models extrapolate for peat samples with larger mineral contents. We emphasize that for peat samples, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ underestimates $\gamma$ and can be interpreted as the largest possible degree of decomposition of the least decomposed component and the smallest possible degree of decomposition of the most decomposed component. Therefore, qualitative evaluations of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ with the cores mentioned above is possible.

## Relation of other decomposition indicators to the degree of decomposition

First, we analyzed the relation between other decomposition indicators (C/N, H/C, O/C, $\delta^{13}$C, $\delta^{15}$N, HI$_{1630/1090}$, $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$, and NOSC) and the degree of decomposition measured in the litterbag samples by computing Pearson correlations and creating scatterplots that differentiate between litter types (plant species and organ).  
Second, we compared the variation of HI$_{1630/1090}$ for the undecomposed litter samples with the variation in the degree of decomposition predicted by the models for the same samples and with the variation of HI$_{1630/1090}$ for all analyzed peat samples with a C content larger than 0.3 g g$^{-1}$, in order to analyze in more detail whether HI$_{1630/1090}$ confounds differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter with decomposition, compared to the suggested decomposition indicator.  
<!--Third, we analyzed the relation between the other decomposition indicators (now also including bulk density) and the degree of decomposition predicted by the models for the peat samples by computing Pearson correlations and creating scatterplots that differentiate between peat cores.-->
<!--To test hypotheses regarding EAC and EDC, we predict EAC and EDC from MIRS for two sets of peat samples: peat samples with *Sphagnum* abundance $>80%$, peat samples with sedge abundance $>60%$, and peat samples with shrub abundance $>60%$ from cores with macrofossil information; and for the litterbag samples, and plot the EAC and EDC versus the suggested degree of decomposition (or the measured degree of decomposition for litter samples).-->
We used models from the irpeat package to predict O/C, H/C, $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$, and NOSC, missing values for bulk density, C and N contents, and C/N, and for all samples humification index HI$_{1630/1090}$ (the ratio of the intensity at 1630 cm$^{-1}$ to the intensity at $1090$ cm$^{-1}$) as defined in @Broder.2012. In many cases, the litter samples are outside the prediction domains of the corresponding models from the irpeatmodels package and therefore may be biased [@Teickner.2023]. For $\delta^{13}$C and $\delta^{15}$N values, the prediction models have large prediction errors and we therefore omitted missing values in our analyses. For these reasons, we consider our analysis of the relation of the degree of decomposition to O/C, H/C, $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$, and NOSC as exploratory analyses. To make clear whether values are measured or predicted from MIRS, we label all MIRS predicted variables with a subscript "MIRS", for example C$_\text{MIRS}$, or use graphical means to differentiate measurements from predictions.


## Underestimation of the degree of decomposition by $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ in two-component systems {#dd-methods-bias-simulations}

As outlined in the Introduction, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ may underestimate $\gamma$ for multi-component systems because more decomposed components contribute less to the MIRS signal than less decomposed components. To our knowledge, this bias, which is also relevant for many other decomposition indicators (see the Discussion), has not been analyzed yet and it is also not mentioned in recent reviews of peat decomposition indicators [@Biester.2014; @Zaccone.2018]. We analyzed the bias with two simulations. The first simulation calculates the bias for a two-component system and analyzes how it depends on the relative mass fractions and the degree of decomposition of each component. The second simulation creates two-component systems by mixing the litter samples used for model development in different ratios and then using the models to predict $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$. Since we know the degree of decomposition for each litter type, we can compare $\gamma$ to $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ predicted by our models.

### Simulation 1 {#dd-methods-bias-simulation-1}

Let $m_i(t)$ be the mass of component $i$ of a peat sample at time $t$, $t_0$ be the time at which a layer was initially formed, such that $m_i(t_0)$ is considered the initial mass. Then the degree of decomposition of component $i$ at time $t$ is $\gamma_i(t) = \frac{m_i(t_0) - m_i(t)}{m_i(t_0)}$. The degree of decomposition of a peat sample (multi-component system) is:

\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
\gamma(t) &=& 1 - \frac{m(t)}{m(t_0)} &=& \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t_0) \gamma_i(t)}{m(t_0)},
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-1)
\end{aligned}
\end{equation} 

where $m(t)$ is the mass of the sample at time $t$, $m(t_0)$ the mass of the undecomposed sample. In contrast, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ is:

\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t) &=& \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t) \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)}{m(t)},
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-2)
\end{aligned}
\end{equation} 

where $\gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)$ is the degree of decomposition of component $i$. Thus, in a multi-component system, the signal of each component ($\gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)$) is weighted by its mass fraction at the time of sampling and not by its mass fraction in the undecomposed sample; components with larger degree of decomposition will therefore contribute less to the signal of the sample than components with smaller degree of decomposition.  
We analyzed the bias in $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ as the difference $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t) - \gamma(t)$, assuming that for the individual components, $\gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t) = \gamma_i(t)$, i.e. the MIRS model perfectly predicts $\gamma_i(t)$ for each component:

\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t) - \gamma(t) &=& \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t) \gamma_{\text{MIRS},i}(t)}{m(t)} - \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t_0) \gamma_i(t)}{m(t_0)}\\ 
&=& \frac{\sum_i^n m_i(t) \gamma_{i}(t)m(t_0) - m(t)m(t_0) + m^2(t)}{m(t) m(t_0)}
\end{aligned}
(\#eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-3)
\end{equation}

In our simulation, we use two components with mass fractions of component 1 ranging from `r range(dd_simulation_2$mf_1_1) |> knitr::combine_words(and = " to ")` g g$^{-1}$ and degree of decomposition of both components ranging from `r range(dd_simulation_2$gamma_1) |> knitr::combine_words(and = " to ")` g g$^{-1}$.

### Simulation 2

We preprocessed all litter spectra (interpolation, clipping, baseline correction, area normalization). For `r paste0("*", dd_simulation_3_species |> stringr::str_replace("[A-Z]{1}.+ ", paste0(stringr::str_sub(dd_simulation_3_species, 1, 1), ". ")), "*") |> knitr::combine_words()`, we selected one undecomposed litter sample and in addition three of the litterbag samples with intermediate degree of decomposition. The spectra of these samples were scaled in the same range as component 1 in simulation 1. We then selected a second set of spectra consisting of the 5 most decomposed litter samples and added these to each of the spectra from the first set, resulting in a total of `r dd_simulation_3 |> dplyr::filter(taxon_rank_value %in% dd_simulation_3_species) |> nrow()` spectra. We predicted $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ with all three models for these mixtures, calculated $\gamma(t)$ and the bias ($\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t) - \gamma(t)$), which we compared to the theoretically expected bias, calculated as in simulation 1.

## Reconstruction of past *Sphagnum* NPP {#dd-methods-reonstruction-npp}

Besides testing peatland models, a potential application of a decomposition indicator that directly estimates the degree of decomposition is to reconstruct initial layer masses by dividing the mass of a peat sample by the fraction of initial mass remaining ($1 - \gamma(t)$). Since $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ underestimates $\gamma(t)$, this approach also underestimates the initial mass or NPP and we therefore call an approach that reconstructs initial layer masses with an uncorrected $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ a naive reconstruction of initial masses (or NPP in the absence of roots). Based on the results of our simulations described in the previous subsection, we suggest that under some conditions the naive approach can be used to approximately reconstruct past aboveground NPP of individual litter types (see the Discussion, subsection \@ref(dd-discussion-gamma-mirs-bias), and supporting section \@ref(si-dd-naive-reconstruction-applied)). For the dated peat cores (MH1, MK1, OD2), we used this approach to estimate the average NPP for some *Sphagnum* species and compare these estimates to measured *Sphagnum* NPP from previous studies. The details of this analysis are described in supporting section \@ref(si-dd-naive-reconstruction-applied).

```{r}
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    elpd_diff_is_significant = elpd_diff != max(elpd_diff) & elpd_diff + 2 * se_diff <= 0.0
  )
```


All models have a similar fit to the training data (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-15)) and similar predictive performance as measured by their ELPD durig CV (Tab. \@ref(tab:dd-tab-loo-comparison-1)). Model `r dd_stan_1_kfold_2_comparison_df |> dplyr::arrange(elpd_diff) |> dplyr::slice(length(elpd_diff)) |> dplyr::pull(model_name)` had the best average predictive accuracy (= maximum average ELPD) for the stratified CV and model `r dd_stan_1_kfold_comparison_df |> dplyr::arrange(elpd_diff) |> dplyr::slice(length(elpd_diff)) |> dplyr::pull(model_name)` for the grouped CV. Using a normal approximation for $\Delta$ELPD and a two-sided significance level of 5%, only model `r dd_stan_1_kfold_2_comparison_df |> dplyr::filter(elpd_diff_is_significant) |> dplyr::pull(model_name)` in the stratified CV `r if(any(dd_stan_1_kfold_comparison_df$elpd_diff_is_significant) || ! all(dd_stan_1_kfold_2_comparison_df$model_name[dd_stan_1_kfold_2_comparison_df$elpd_diff_is_significant] == dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info))) {stop("[---todo: check if(any(dd_stan_1_kfold_comparison_df$elpd_diff_is_significant ||...]")}` has a detectably worse predictive accuracy than the model with best average ELPD (Tab. \@ref(tab:dd-tab-loo-comparison-1)). Large errors of $\Delta$ELPD in the grouped CV indicate a large variability in predictive performance of the model for the different folds, as expected when testing the model with litter samples from species not included in the training data.  
For all models, the fit to the training data is better on average (smaller average RMSE) than for predictions in the two CV scenarios (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-15)), indicating that all models overfit. The two models using derivative spectra had the, on average, best fit to the training data, but worse or not much better predictive accuracy in the CV scenarios, indicating an, on average, larger overfitting risk than for model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)`, which does not use derivative spectra.  
Predictive accuracy of all models was worse for the grouped CV than for the stratified CV (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-15)), as expected, because in the stratified CV models were tested with samples from similar studies and species as the data they were trained with, whereas in the grouped CV some folds contained samples from species the model was not trained with. In the grouped CV, $\gamma$ is underestimated by all models for decomposed *T. latifolia* and *S. capillifolium* samples from @Arsenault.2024a. Conversely, $\gamma$ is overestimated for undecomposed litter samples, with prediction errors larger than 10% for model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` for `r dd_data_model_evaluation_1 |> dplyr::filter(id_model == 1 & cv_type == "Grouped CV" & abs(y - yhat_mean) > 0.1 & y <= 0.01) |> dplyr::mutate(taxon_rank_value = paste0("*", taxon_rank_value, "*")) |> dplyr::pull(taxon_rank_value) |> unique() |> knitr::combine_words()`, and for the other two models for `r dd_data_model_evaluation_1 |> dplyr::filter(id_model != 1 & cv_type == "Grouped CV" & abs(y - yhat_mean) > 0.1 & y <= 0.01) |> dplyr::mutate(taxon_rank_value = paste0("*", taxon_rank_value, "*")) |> dplyr::pull(taxon_rank_value) |> unique() |> knitr::combine_words()`. Model `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` has, both in the grouped and stratified CV, the largest average prediction errors for undecomposed litter (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-15)).

## Model predictions under extrapolation

A comparison of the prediction domains of the models to the spectral range covered by the analyzed peat samples indicates that many of the peat samples have MIRS different to the training data. HI$_{1630/1090}$ as alternative decomposition indicator, C or C$_\text{MIRS}$, and photographs of the peat samples, suggest that samples outside prediction domains are either more decomposed or have large mineral contents (Fig. \@ref(si-fig:dd-plot-17) and \@ref(si-fig:dd-plot-18)), which is not surprising since there are comparatively few decomposed samples and no mineral-rich samples in the training data. Data coverage by prediction domains differs between the models: `r round(sum(dd_data_pmird_peat_cores_yhat[[1]]$degree_of_decomposition_in_pd) / nrow(dd_data_pmird_peat_cores_yhat[[1]]) * 100, digits = 1)`% of the peat samples are within the prediction domain for model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` and `r round(sum(dd_data_pmird_peat_cores_yhat[[2]]$degree_of_decomposition_in_pd) / nrow(dd_data_pmird_peat_cores_yhat[[2]]) * 100, digits = 1)`% and `r round(sum(dd_data_pmird_peat_cores_yhat[[3]]$degree_of_decomposition_in_pd) / nrow(dd_data_pmird_peat_cores_yhat[[3]]) * 100, digits = 1)`% for the other two models, which indicates that derivative spectra differ more between the peat and the training data data than underived spectra. Thus, the models extrapolate for more decomposed and mineral-rich peat and the prediction domain of model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` covers most of the peat samples.

Thus, if one considers that the training data contains decomposed litter only from three species, the fit of the models may be confounded by proteins and this may bias predictions, especially under extrapolation.--> A plot of residuals versus N$_\text{MIRS}$ for different levels of the degree of decomposition suggests that model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` underestimates the degree of decomposition for samples in the training data with a degree of decomposition between ca. 20 and 40% and N$_\text{MIRS}$ content smaller than ca. 0.02 g g$^{-1}$ (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-8)). For the models computed with derivative spectra, this bias is smaller (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-8)). We analyzed the robustness of the models under extrapolation for decomposed and mineral-rich samples. As we did not have access to independent validation data, we conducted qualitative sensitivity analyses by selecting some litter samples from the training data, adding multiples of spectra of a silicate-dominated or a very decomposed (based on HI$_{1630/1090}$, peat structure, C content, and degree of decomposition predicted by all models), and then predicting the degree of decomposition for these modified spectra.   
For silicates, prediction errors of all models increase the more silicates are mixed into the samples such that 95% prediction intervals cover nearly the whole range of possible degrees of decomposition (Fig. \@ref(si-fig:dd-plot-1-1) to \@ref(si-fig:dd-plot-1-3)). The behavior of predicted medians differs between the models. For model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)`, predictions overall increase for undecomposed samples and decrease for more decomposed samples, but the differences are never larger than ca. 30%. Model `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` behaves similar, but predictions always increase with more silicate influence and differences to the true value may exceed 50%. For model `r dd_model_names(2, dd_model_info)` predictions decrease with more silicate influence for all but the undecomposed samples and compared to the other models more posterior probability is placed on smaller degrees of decomposition.  
For decomposed peat, the median predicted degree of decomposition increases for all samples and models, as expected when adding a highly decomposed peat sample to less decomposed litter samples (Fig. \@ref(si-fig:dd-plot-5-1) to \@ref(si-fig:dd-plot-5-3)). Median predictions for the maximum addition of the decomposed peat are smallest for model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` and largest for model `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)`. As for the silicate experiment, also prediction errors of all models increase the more of the decomposed sample is mixed into the samples, but prediction intervals are narrower than for the silicate experiment and, especially for already decomposed litters, their width also differs between models: Model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` estimates the largest prediction errors and prediction errors increase the more of the decomposed peat is added to a sample, even for decomposed litter. Model `r dd_model_names(2, dd_model_info)` and in particular model `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` have narrower prediction intervals for already decomposed litter, but in most of the cases predictions do not differ significantly from those of model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)`. Thus, model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` estimates a smaller median degree of decomposition with larger prediction errors than the models using derivative spectra.   

## Application to peat cores

Application of the models to peat cores from the drained and partly rewetted Venner Moor supports the sensitivity analysis results (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-10-2) (a)): Models `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` and `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` predict a large degree of decomposition for the decomposed (based on C/N, HI$_{1630/1090}$, peat structure) pre-drainage peat, and a small degree of decomposition for the peat formed since rewetting. Similarly, for the drained and forested core, both models correctly predict a small degree of decomposition for the top 5 cm, followed by more decomposed peat from the drainage acrotelm. Also, a smaller degree of decomposition in the mid part of the profile, which is still water saturated, and an increase in the degree of decomposition in the bottom part agree with C/N, HI$_{1630/1090}$, and peat structure. This analysis suggests that, even though many of the peat samples are not within the prediction domain of the models and we did not correct $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ for multi-component systems, the suggested decomposition indicator currently can at least identify qualitative differences in the degree of decomposition.  
Application of the models to peat cores with volcanic ash layers from Patagonia also supports results from the sensitivity analysis (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-10-2) (b)): Whenever mineral contents are large (as indicated by smaller C$_\text{MIRS}$ compared to adjacent layers), prediction errors are large. In addition, for the ash layer at 170 cm depth in core PBR 2, model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` and `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` predict a larger median degree of decomposition than model `r dd_model_names(2, dd_model_info)` which is consistent with results from the sensitivity analysis and indicates that model `r dd_model_names(2, dd_model_info)` may less reliably extrapolate for samples with large mineral contents. An interesting observation is that each model can predict different degree of decomposition values for samples with similar mineral content in core PBR 2 (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-10-2) (b)): For the ash layer at 170 cm depth, all models predict a larger median degree of decomposition whereas they predict a smaller median degree of decomposition for the bottom mineral layer. This may indicate that the suggested decomposition indicator or an improved version of it can predict the degree of decomposition for samples with moderate mineral contents, unlike humification indices (HI$_{1630/1090}$ also shown in the plots) that are also computed from MIRS, but suggest a smaller degree of decomposition in both cases.  
Since model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` underestimates the degree of decomposition for training samples with intermediate degree of decomposition and N content smaller than 0.02 g g$^{-1}$, smaller estimates for $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ by model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` for cores from the Venner Moor and Patagonian cores are probably underestimates.

In (b), approximate position of ash layers from @Broder.2012 are shown as grey bands.

$\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ will underestimate $\gamma(t)$ of a peat sample with two components, except when the two components have the same degree of decomposition. Generally, this bias is worse the more the degree of decomposition differs between the components and the smaller the fraction of the more decomposed component in the sample is (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-22)). Thus, the maximum possible bias depends in a complex way on the degree of decomposition of the components and their mass fractions (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-22)).

## Relation of other decomposition indicators to the degree of decomposition

For the litter samples used in litterbag experiments (*Sphagnum capillifolium*, *Typha latifolia*, and *Phragmites australis*), Pearson correlations between other decomposition indicators and the measured degree of decomposition have the expected sign (positive for  HI$_{1630/1090}$, $\delta^{15}$N, $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$; negative for C/N, H/C, O/C, and NOSC; mixed for $\delta^{13}$C depending on the relative importance of isotope fractionation versus enrichment of $^{13}$C-depleted compounds), but they confound differences in litter chemistry between species and plant organs with decomposition (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-12)). For undecomposed litter from all species, HI$_{1630/1090}$ varies in a larger range than for all peat samples with a C content larger than 0.3 g g$^{-1}$, whereas all models accurately reproduce that the samples are not decomposed (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-11)).

## Reconstruction of past average *Sphagnum* NPP

```{r}
dd_reconstruction_initial_mass_rate_1_summary <- 
  dd_reconstruction_initial_mass_rate_1 |>
  dplyr::select(taxon_rank_value, core_label, id_model, degree_of_decomposition, initial_mass_rate, degree_of_decomposition_in_pd) |>
  dplyr::group_by(taxon_rank_value, core_label, id_model) |>
  dplyr::summarise(
    dplyr::across(
      dplyr::all_of(c("degree_of_decomposition", "initial_mass_rate")),
      posterior::rvar_mean
    ),
    degree_of_decomposition_in_pd = sum(degree_of_decomposition_in_pd)/length(degree_of_decomposition_in_pd),
    .groups = "drop"
  )
```


Table \@ref(tab:dd-tab-dd-reconstruction-initial-mass-rate-1) summarizes estimates of past *Sphagnum* NPP for each core and species or species group, using the degree of decomposition estimated by each of the three models, and Fig. \@ref(si-fig:dd-plot-20) shows estimates for individual layers versus time. Since all analyzed layers have a relative small degree of decomposition, according to all models, the estimates do not differ much between models when their errors are considered. # Discussion

In order to improve peatland models and the interpretation of peat cores, we suggested properties of an ideal decomposition indicator and based on this developed models that predict the degree of decomposition ($\gamma$) in litterbag experiments from MIRS ($\gamma_\text{MIRS}$). In addition, we analyzed how other commonly used decomposition indicators (C/N, H/C, O/C, $\delta^{13}$C, $\delta^{15}$N, HI$_{1630/1090}$, $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$, and NOSC) relate to $\gamma$. This allows us to better illustrate limitations of existing decomposition indicators (subsection \@ref(dd-discussion-other-di-1)), in particular how they confound differences in litter chemistry with decomposition, than previous studies and to evaluate our prediction models and advantages and disadvantages of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ (subsections \@ref(dd-discussion-gamma-mirs-advantages-1) and \@ref(dd-discussion-gamma-mirs-model-evaluation-1)). We argue that $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ has advantages as qualitative and also as absolute decomposition indicator. At the same time, improvements of the prediction models is desirable to better achieve these advantages and we outline opportunities to do so (subsection \@ref(dd-discussion-improvements)).  
We also identified a new source of error of many decomposition indicators, including $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$: the underestimation of $\gamma$ in multi-component systems, and analyzed in detail the magnitude of this bias depending on the degree of decomposition and relative proportions of the components. When the aim is to estimate the degree of decomposition on an absolute scale, this bias cannot be neglected, and it will also distort interpretation of qualitative decomposition indicators because the bias is not linear. In subsection \@ref(dd-discussion-gamma-mirs-bias), we present strategies how to avoid or correct this bias in different settings. Using one of these strategies, we estimated the degree of decomposition of *Sphagnum* species in layers up to several thousand years old from three peat cores and also reconstruct their NPP (subsection \@ref(dd-discussion-naive-reconstruction)). In addition, we discuss how a multi-component analysis of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ can be used to estimate litter-specific decomposition rates and the slow-down of decomposition due to increasing litter recalcitrance (subsection \@ref(dd-discussion-analysis-of-long-term-decomposition)), both factors that introduce large errors into peat accumulation simulated with process models [@Frolking.2001; @Quillet.2013; @Teickner.2025f] and that are assumed to not be measurable with litterbag experiments or peat accumulation data [@Clymo.1998; @Frolking.2001; @Teickner.2025]. Thus, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ can be useful to improve process models, and $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ may be an alternative or supplement to process models for the reconstruction of past NPP from peat cores.

We have developed models that predict the degree of decomposition from MIRS ($\gamma_\text{MIRS}$) that were preprocessed in different ways and conducted quantitative and qualitative checks for predictive accuracy and robustness under extrapolation, considering differences in nitrogen contents, mineral contents, and mixtures of undecomposed and very decomposed samples. Here, we discuss to what extent these models fulfill properties of an ideal decomposition indicator, how their predictions compare among each other, how they can be improved, and what the advantages and disadvantages of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ are compared to other decomposition indicators.

## Suitability of other decomposition indicators {#dd-discussion-other-di-1}

```{r, eval = FALSE}
d <- 
  tidyr::expand_grid(
    gamma_1 = seq(0, 0.999, by = 0.1),
    gamma_2 = 0,
    m_1_0 = seq(0.1, 100, length.out = 20)
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    oc_0 = 0.3,
    oc_1_1 = oc_0 + 4 * gamma_1,
    oc_2_1 = oc_0 + 4 * gamma_2,
    m_2_0 = 1,
    m_0 = m_1_0 + m_2_0,
    m_1_1 = m_1_0 * (1 - gamma_1),
    m_2_1 = m_2_0 * (1 - gamma_2),
    m_1 = m_1_1 + m_2_1,  
    mf_1_1 = m_1_1/m_1,
    oc_1 = (oc_1_1 * m_1_1 + oc_2_1 * m_2_1) / m_1,
    oci_1 = oc_0 * m_0 / m_1,
    gamma_oci = 1 - oc_0/oci_1,
    gamma_oc = (oc_1 - oc_0) / 4,
    gamma = (gamma_1 * m_1_0 + gamma_2 * m_2_0) / m_0,
    gamma_mirs = (gamma_1 * m_1_1 + gamma_2 * m_2_1) / m_1
  )
```

Many other peat properties have been suggested as decomposition indicators. Unlike previous studies, we directly analyzed how C/N and humification indices (e.g., HI$_{1630/1090}$) confound differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter with decomposition. Our results suggest that C/N and HI$_{1630/1090}$ vary as much for undecomposed litter samples as for the peat samples analyzed in this study (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-11)). This is because of the large variability of N and protein contents in litter of different species grown under different conditions [e.g., @Limpens.2003] (in particular, for the *P. australis* rhizomes grown under different N supply [@Reuter.2020]), the variability of aromatic contents, and because of the contribution of both aromatics and proteins to MIRS intensities at 1510 and 1630 cm$^{-1}$ [@Stuart.2004]. In addition, for C/N, one also needs to consider that, when C/N is small, much more C needs to be lost to change C/N by one unit, than when C/N is large. This implies larger slopes of C/N versus degree of decomposition for litter with large initial C/N, as observable in Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-12), unless N is lost at a larger rate, which may even reverse the relation of C/N and HI$_{1630/1090}$ to the degree of decomposition, as is the case for high-N *P. australis* rhizomes (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-12)). For similar reasons as for C/N and HI$_{1630/1090}$, $\delta^{13}$C and $\delta^{15}$N also confound differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter with decomposition (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-12)) [@Asada.2005; @Asada.2005a; @Bowling.2008].  
Theory suggests that O/C, H/C, and NOSC decrease during decomposition due to loss of carbohydrates (rich in H and O) and relative accumulation of aromatics (rich in C) and theory suggests that, because of the larger relative loss of more oxidized compounds which implies a more positive enthalpy of formation [e.g., @Popovic.2019], $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$ increases during decomposition. The sign of the relations to the degree of decomposition in our analysis of litterbag and peat samples agrees with theory (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-12)), indicating that, even though O/C, H/C, NOSC, and $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$ were predicted from MIRS and the spectra are different from the respective training data, relative differences between predictions of these decomposition indicators for the same litter type are not obviously wrong.    
Theory also suggests that O/C, H/C, NOSC, and $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$ confound differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter with decomposition because we know that different species (or organs of the same plant) differ in the relative fraction of holocellulose, lignin, and lipids [e.g., @Scheffer.2001; @Bengtsson.2018], we know that holocellulose, lignin, and lipids differ in their H/O/C stoichiometry, NOSC is computed from this stoichiometry [@Masiello.2008; @LaRowe.2011], and we know that $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$ is mostly controlled by the number of electrons transferred during oxidation which also depends on the H/O/C stoichiometry [@Thornton.1917; @Patel.1981; @Popovic.2019]. It is thus known that O/C, H/C, NOSC, and $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$ confound differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter with decomposition, but not how large the difference is for different species. Based on our analysis, we suggest that relative differences in O/C, H/C, NOSC, and $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$ across different undecomposed litter types are similar to that in C/N and HI$_{1630/1090}$, meaning that they may cover the range of changes observable when one specific litter type is decomposed (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-12)). This hypothesis needs to be tested with direct measurements or with more information about the robustness of the irpeat models under extrapolation.<!-- because our analyses for the relation between O/C, H/C, NOSC, and $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$ to the degree of decomposition are currently not reliable.-->  
All previously suggested decomposition indicators that we analyzed here measure a peat property that changes nonlinearly when another component with different degree of decomposition is added to a sample. This is because each of them is a quantity normalized by one of: the total amount of C (O/C, H/C, NOSC, $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$), the total amount of N (C/N), the amount of a specific stable isotope ($\delta^{13}$C, $\delta^{15}$N), or the total amount of molecular structures (HI$_{1630/1090}$). Therefore, all these decomposition indicators will underestimate the degree of decomposition in multi-component systems in the same way as $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$, as outlined in the Introduction, analyzed in sections \@ref(dd-methods-bias-simulations) and \@ref(dd-methods-bias-simulations-results), and described by equation \@ref(eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-3). To our knowledge, this problem has not been described before, as it is not mentioned in recent reviews of decomposition indicators [e.g., @Biester.2014; @Zaccone.2018]; we suggest that this is because decomposition indicators have not been directly compared against $\gamma$, except perhaps in litterbag experiments, where the problem does not occur. Thus, any of the decomposition indicators analyzed here will be nonlinearly related to $\gamma$ in multi-component systems (where the components have a different degree of decomposition), even when they would be linearly related to $\gamma$ for each component individually. The only way to avoid this bias with bulk measurements is to use an approach similar to the ash residue method, where the signal (the mass of ash) changes linearly when other components are added to the sample.  
In summary, our study illustrates how C/N, humification indices, $\delta^{13}$C, $\delta^{15}$N, O/C, H/C, NOSC, and $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$ confound differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter with decomposition in one- and two-component systems. This confounding factor is either known empirically or can be deduced from theory, but previous reviews of decomposition indicators [@Biester.2014; @Zaccone.2018] did not estimate how much this factor contributes to the variability of the decomposition indicators and they did not consider how $\gamma$ is underestimated in multi-component systems. Whereas our collection of litter samples may exaggerate differences between litter chemistry that are expected in natural vegetation shifts in peatlands, because hummock *Sphagnum* species will not directly replace *P. australis*, and some of our analyses could be refined empirically, it illustrates the need to check, during each application of the analyzed decomposition indicators, that these decomposition indicators do not confound differences in litter chemistry with decomposition, it illustrates the inability of many decomposition indicators to compare the degree of decomposition between peatland types, and it illustrates that many decomposition indicators underestimate $\gamma$ for multi-component systems. The last point is, of course, less relevant when decomposition indicators are only used in a qualitative way, but it makes it likely that the decomposition indicators are nonlinearly related to the degree of decomposition for bulk peat which makes comparing values, even only in a qualitative way, less straightforward.  
Since these confounding factors depend on differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter, since these differences can be quite complex, and since, typically, chemical properties are used to evaluate the degree of decomposition of peat, it is unlikely that a directly measurable peat property or a simple transformation of measurable peat properties (e.g., humification indices, element ratios) can be an accurate decomposition indicator. In multi-component systems, there will be an additional bias due to the underestimation of the degree of decomposition.
