## When does $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ have advantages as decomposition indicator? {#dd-discussion-gamma-mirs-advantages-1}

Tab. \@ref(tab:dd-table-1) summarizes which of the properties of an ideal decomposition indicator are fulfilled by different types of decomposition indicators. Compared to other decomposition indicators, the advantages and disadvantages of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ depend on whether the aim is to estimate the degree of decomposition on an absolute scale (absolute decomposition indicator) or to only have a qualitative decomposition indicator, and whether a one-component system (e.g., one litter type) or a multi-component system (peat sample consisting of more than one litter type) is analyzed.  
When the aim is to use $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ as qualitative decomposition indicator for a one-component system, there are a couple of advantages compared to qualitative decomposition indicators, such as C/N or humification indices: Unlike many qualitative decomposition indicators, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is more consistent in estimating a small degree of decomposition for diverse types of undecomposed litter (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-12) and \@ref(fig:dd-plot-11)). This makes values of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ more comparable between different samples from one or different peat cores. Unlike humification indices, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ indicates that it cannot accurately predict the degree of decomposition when a sample has a large mineral content.  
For a multi-component system, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ retains these advantages as qualitative decomposition indicator, except that values are not directly comparable between samples with differences in the relative proportions and degrees of decomposition of different components (Tab. \@ref(tab:dd-table-1)). However, as discussed in the previous section, the majority of other decomposition indicators shares this limitation. Thus, if MIRS are measured anyways for a sample, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is a better alternative as a qualitative decomposition indicator than humification indices. If not confounding differences in litter chemistry with decomposition is critical (for example because contrasting systems are analyzed and compared), $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ may also be more useful than other decomposition indicators that do not have this property, for example C/N.  
The main advantage of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is that it is the only absolute decomposition indicator we are aware of, besides $\gamma_\text{ARM}$, and may therefore help to address some fundamental research questions on long-term dynamics of decomposition and NPP, as outlined in the Introduction. When one-component systems are analyzed, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ shares all advantages of $\gamma_\text{ARM}$ and in addition does not require us to know the initial state of the sample, which is a large error source of $\gamma_\text{ARM}$, as mentioned in the Introduction (Tab. \@ref(tab:dd-table-1)). For more decomposed samples, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ may have larger errors than $\gamma_\text{ARM}$ because of prediction errors and because the models developed here were not trained on samples with large degree of decomposition which causes comparatively large extrapolation errors.  
When multi-component systems are analyzed, $\gamma_\text{ARM}$ is not biased because the mass of ash is independent of the degree of decomposition of the sample or its components. In contrast, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ underestimates the degree of decomposition (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-22) and \@ref(fig:dd-plot-23-2)), but this bias can be addressed when using $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ to test peatland models, or it can be avoided by a component-specific analysis, if one is willing to add extra effort during the laboratory analyses; in both cases, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ will retain the possible advantage of smaller errors because no initial states of the sample need to be estimated. As mentioned in the Introduction, a component-specific analysis offers novel ways to better test peatland models, reconstruct past NPP from peat cores without process models, and analyze peat core data over time ranges previously inaccessible except with computer simulations. Thus, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ has merits both when used as qualitative decomposition indicator and, in particular, when quantitative analyses and reconstructions are needed.  

<!--Well-tested Decomposition indicators that estimate the degree of decomposition on an absolute scale are needed for progress in interpreting peat cores and understanding the processes that formed it. A good example for this is that $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ allowed us to detect this bias and, likewise, other error sources -->



## Evaluation of the prediction models for $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ {#dd-discussion-gamma-mirs-model-evaluation-1}

The advantages of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ depend on how accurate we can predict $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ for individual litter types. Our model evaluation addressed this question by estimating the predictive performance for novel data, testing qualitative model behavior for samples with large mineral contents, samples where a decomposed component is added, and how proteins may bias predictions. There are both encouraging results and open limitations that can be addressed in future studies to improve the models. Encouraging results are:

1. All models make accurately fit the training data. In particular, they accurately estimate a small degree of decomposition for a diverse set of undecomposed litter samples, unlike humification indices, and they accurately fit the degree of decomposition for litter types from different species and with different degree of decomposition.

2. Our residual analysis suggests that, for the training data, models `r dd_model_names(2, dd_model_info)` and `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` at most slightly confound differences in N content with decomposition. There is some indication that model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` confounds differences in N content with decomposition, but it may be possible to address this limitation with more training data from decomposed samples.  

3. For mixtures of spectra with larger mineral contents than in the training data, all models estimate large prediction errors and prediction intervals that cover all possible values of the degree of decomposition. While it may not be the case that including training data with mineral admixtures can improve the predictive accuracy because of complex interference between infrared peaks caused by minerals and organic matter [e.g., @Stuart.2004; @Parikh.2014], the large prediction errors avoid misinterpretations and therefore are an improvement over humification indices, which estimate a smaller degree of decomposition for peat samples with large mineral contents [e.g., @Broder.2012].

4. For mixtures of spectra of undecomposed litter with a very decomposed peat sample, models `r dd_model_names(2, dd_model_info)` and `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` correctly predicted increasing degrees of decomposition the more of the peat sample was added. Moreover, the models correctly identified peat layers with large degree of decomposition in drained peat cores as well as a small degree of decomposition in layers formed since rewetting and, based on C/N, humification indices, and photographs, less decomposed peat not impacted by drainage. This suggests that $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ can be used as qualitative decomposition indicator because it makes sensible predictions undecomposed litter and for more decomposed peat, despite the lack of training data and the underestimation of $\gamma$ for multi-component systems; these results indicate that $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ can identify qualitative differences in the degree of decomposition similar to existing decomposition indicators while having advantages that were discussed in subsection \@ref(dd-discussion-gamma-mirs-advantages-1).

Limitations are:

1. Currently, it is difficult to recommend a best model because the models have trade-offs that need to be evaluated with additional data. Our recommendation is to consider the variability of model predictions until further tests have been performed (see subsection \@ref(dd-discussion-improvements)).  
Model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` fits the data worse and underestimates the degree of decomposition most for *T. latifolia* and *S. capillifolium* samples with N content < 0.02 g g$^{-1}$ and therefore probably underestimates the degree of decomposition for many peat samples and compared to the other two models. However, it has the best average predictive performance in the stratified CV, which we think best approximates possible applications of the models to peat samples, and it is also the model that confounds the least differences in initial litter chemistry with decomposition in the CV (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-15)).  
Model `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` overfits the data most, based on the stratified CV, and confounds the most differences in initial litter chemistry with decomposition in the CV (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-15)), but when trained on all data, it fits the degree of decomposition best and does not confound difference in the chemistry of decomposed litter with decomposition, and it does not underestimate the degree of decomposition for *T. latifolia* and *S. capillifolium* samples with N content < 0.02 g g$^{-1}$.  
In all aspects mentioned in the previous two points, model `r dd_model_names(2, dd_model_info)` is intermediate between the other two models and in addition has the best average predictive performance in the stratified CV. However, even though 95% prediction intervals also cover the complete possible range for samples with large mineral contents, the median predicted degree of decomposition and bulk of the posterior distribution decrease the more minerals are within a sample. 

2. For most peat samples, the models extrapolate because the spectra are different from those of the training data. Application of the models to the peat samples suggest that in many of these cases the peat samples are more decomposed. The extrapolation risk can therefore be reduced with litterbag data from more diverse litter types and long-term litterbag experiments that produce highly decomposed litter (see Section \@ref(dd-discussion-improvements)).

The next subsection gives recommendations how these limitations can be addressed.

2. Model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` has a worse fit to the data and underestimates the degree of decomposition most for *T. latifolia* and *S. capillifolium* samples with N content < 0.02 g g$^{-1}$ (and therefore probably underestimates the degree of decomposition for many peat samples and compared to the other two models), but it has the best average predictive performance in the stratified CV, which we think best approximates possible applications of the models to peat samples, and it is also the model that confounds the least differences in initial litter chemistry with decomposition in the CV (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-15)).

3. Model `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` overfits the data most, based on the stratified CV, and confounds the most differences in initial litter chemistry with decomposition in the CV (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-15)), but when trained on all data, it fits the degree of decomposition best and does not confound difference in the chemistry of decomposed litter with decomposition, and it does not underestimate the degree of decomposition for *T. latifolia* and *S. capillifolium* samples with N content < 0.02 g g$^{-1}$.

4. In all aspects mentioned in the previous two points, model `r dd_model_names(2, dd_model_info)` is intermediate between the other two models and in addition has the best average predictive performance in the stratified CV. 5. Some of the litter samples that we classified as undecomposed may have already experienced some initial decomposition, in particular the *Sphagnum* samples for which it is difficult to distinguish dead-but-undecomposed from decomposed parts. We therefore suggest future studies to test whether the models indeed underestimate the degree of decomposition for undecomposed *Sphagnum* litter.-->

## How can we improve the suggested decomposition indicator? {#dd-discussion-improvements}

The important idea of our study is to define the properties an ideal decomposition indicator must fulfill and then to develop a strategy to produce such an indicator. A main advantage of this strategy is that the models that predict $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ can be directly tested in litterbag experiments because they make probabilistic predictions of the expected mass loss on an absolute scale. This offers the opportunity to vary litter type, sample preprocessing methods, and incubation environment in litterbag experiments, and thus to identify the conditions under which the models need to be improved.  
As discussed in the previous subsection, the cross-validation indicates that, while the models are more robust for novel litter types than many existing decomposition indicators, the models may not in general be robust to novel litter types, in particular more decomposed samples of litter types not included in the training data. Our results also indicate proteins and minerals as potential confounding factors. This suggests the following potential studies to improve $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$:

1. Litterbag experiments for litter types not yet included in the training data. This is, in particular: more decomposed hummock *Sphagnum* litter, litter from hollow and lawn *Sphagnum* species, litter from sedges and shrubs. These litterbag experiments should ensure that a large enough range of the degree of decomposition is considered. A possible confounding factor that needs to be addressed is initial leaching losses: if initial leaching losses due to sample preprocessing are different in magnitude and quality from initial leaching losses of unprocessed litter [@Barlocher.1997; @Teickner.2025], this may confound changes in MIRS during decomposition. 

2. Litter from litterbag experiments can be mixed with different minerals, MIRS recorded for the different mixtures, and the models applied to these spectra. Since we already know that prediction errors of the models increase when mineral contents increase, such a study would mainly be interesting to test whether the models computed with the mineral-enriched samples as additional training data produce more accurate predictions for samples with different amounts of minerals.

3. Litter of the same species with different protein content can be grown [e.g., @Reuter.2020] and litter of the same species can be decomposed under different environmental conditions that change relative rates of decomposition of different organic matter fractions (e.g., proteins, carbohydrates, etc. [@Benner.1984; @Reuter.2020]) to test whether differences in litter chemistry changes under such conditions confound predictions of the models.

We proposed to use MIRS as predictor variables because MIRS provide information on many molecular structures and also structural integrity due to hydrogen bonds (e.g. crystalline vs amorphous fractions of cellulose [@Schmidt.2006] or hydrogen bonds of different stability between lignin molecules [@Kubo.2005]) which may change linearly with decomposition and can be sorted out in linear regression with regularizing priors. However, similar prediction models as proposed here could be developed using other peat properties as predictors, for example Nuclear Magnetic Resonance measurements [e.g., @Serk.2022a] or a combination of previously used decomposition indicators, and these may or may not have a better predictive accuracy than MIRS prediction models. To allow others to test and improve the suggested decomposition indicator, we published raw data, code, and the predictions models [@Teickner.2022d] [---todo:ref].


## Estimating the degree of decomposition with $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ in multi-component systems {#dd-discussion-gamma-mirs-bias}

Our simulation analysis where we made predictions on mixed MIRS agrees with our theoretical analysis that $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ underestimates the degree of decomposition when it is computed from a MIRS of the whole peat sample. The consistently more negative bias than theoretically expected (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-23-2)) may be explained by the following mechanism: Litterbag samples, when decomposed, are no mixtures of organic matter fractions with strongly different degree of decomposition because a uniform sample is decomposed in the same way. If mixtures as simulated here emphasize spectral features of undecomposed litter that are used for prediction, the models may underestimate $\gamma$ more than theoretically expected. For example, usually when carbohydrates are decomposed, lipids are selectively enriched and therefore carbohydrate peaks and lipid peaks are negatively related in a litterbag sample. However, mixing two components with different degree of decomposition may result in spectra that have both pronounced carbohydrate and lipid peaks because these are the dominant peaks in the undecomposed and decomposed fraction, respectively.  
As outlined in the Introduction, there are three strategies to estimate the degree of decomposition of multi-component systems with $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$:

1. The approach offering the greatest opportunities and completely avoiding the bias is a component-specific analysis: The components of a sample are separated, a MIRS is recorded for each component, and the degree of decomposition is estimated for each component with the models. If an estimate for the degree of decomposition of the sample is needed, this can be directly estimated from the measurements using equation \@ref(eq:eq-dd-gamma-bias-1). Future research is necessary to check whether it is possible to separate litter types from peat samples, such that this approach works in practice.

2. For bulk peat, when not correcting the bias, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ can still be interpreted as the largest possible degree of decomposition of the least decomposed component and the smallest possible degree of decomposition of the most decomposed component.

3. For bulk peat, when not correcting the bias but applying $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ under certain conditions and interpretations, the bias is small enough to be acceptable for many purposes and in comparison to errors of the ash residue method. In these cases, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is therefore a good approximation for $\gamma$ because the bias is small.  

To concretize the third strategy, we suggest that only small errors are made for the following conditions and interpretations of $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$:

1. Differences in the degree of decomposition of the components of a peat sample as large as in our theoretical simulation can occur when roots grow into decomposed peat. In this case, roots are the less decomposed component. Then, according to our simulation, if the mass fraction of the roots does not exceed `r dd_simulation_2_threshold_m_1_1_f_1`% and the remaining peat has a uniform degree of decomposition, then the expected bias is smaller than 10% (Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-22)).

2. The difference in the degree of decomposition of litter types decomposing under the same environmental conditions is, according to decomposition formulas used in conceptual and more mechanistic models [@Clymo.1984; @Frolking.2001], only a function of the litter-specific decomposition rate constants, which differ between litter types, and of the decomposition progress (the environmental modulation of the decomposition rate integrated over time), which is the same within a peat layer formed by aboveground parts (supporting section \@ref(si-dd-rate-differences-1)). This constrains the absolute difference of the degree of decomposition between the two components ($|\gamma_1 - \gamma_2|$) to a range often smaller than the extreme values in our simulation, and much smaller depending on the litter-specific decomposition rate constants, how much decomposition slows down during decomposition, and how far decomposition has proceeded (supporting Fig. \@ref(si-fig:dd-plot-25)). Since both potential litter-specific decomposition rates and how much decomposition slows down are not well known, we refrain from giving specific recommendations, but instead emphasize that component-specific analyses could provide this information and therefore help to establish rules of thumb when $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ can be safel applied. Our simulation indicates that when $|\gamma_1 - \gamma_2| < 0.5$ g g$^{-1}$, $\gamma_1 < 0.9$, and $\gamma_2 < 0.9$, then the worst bias is around `r dd_simulation_2 |> dplyr::filter(! is.na(bias) & abs(gamma_1 - gamma_2) <= 0.5 & gamma_1 < 0.9 & gamma_2 < 0.9) |> dplyr::pull(bias) |> min() |> round(2)` g g$^{-1}$. Therefore, $|\gamma_1 - \gamma_2| < 0.5$ g g$^{-1}$, $\gamma_1 < 0.9$, and $\gamma_2 < 0.9$ appears to be a reasonable threshold for identifying conditions where $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ does not underestimate $\gamma(t)$ much.

Thus, under some conditions, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}(t)$ can be used as estimate for the degree of decomposition of a dominant component of a peat sample. This justifies our estimation of past *Sphagnum* NPP in peat layers where the volumetric fraction of *Sphagnum* is at least 90% (subsection \@ref(dd-methods-reonstruction-npp)).

The next two subsections discuss how the last approach can be used to reconstruct Holocene *Sphagnum* NPP and to estimate decomposition rate differences between litter types and how much decomposition slows down as mass is lost.


## Reconstruction of past net primary production from peat masses and the degree of decomposition {#dd-discussion-naive-reconstruction}

Following the last recommendation in the previous subsection, we reconstructed the NPP of several *Sphagnum* species in peat layers with a *Sphagnum* volume fraction of at least 90% and a degree of decomposition likely smaller than 60%. According to our simulation, if the models predict $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ perfectly, this will underestimate the NPP by at most 20%. We performed calculations with all three models and compared their predictions, as we recommended above, to consider the possible variability in the degree of decomposition and NPP. Our estimates cover the range of NPP for *S. fuscum* from different studies compiled by @Bona.2018 ($`r dd_data_bona2018_moss_npp_summary_1 |> dplyr::mutate(dplyr::across(dplyr::starts_with("npp"), function(.x) .x/1000), npp = paste0(round(npp_mean, 2), " \\pm ", round(npp_sd, 2))) |> dplyr::pull(npp)`$ kg $^{-1}$ yr$^{-1}$, average $\pm$ standard deviation) [`r dd_data_bona2018_moss_npp_summary_1 |> dplyr::mutate(reference_id = purrr::map(reference_id, function(.x) paste0("@", .x))) |> dplyr::pull(reference_id) |> unlist() |> unique() |> paste(collapse = "; ")`], and are contained in the wider NPP range measured in monospecific *S. fuscum* patches in @Bengtsson.2021 (`r dd_data_bengtsson2021_moss_npp_summary_1 |> dplyr::mutate(dplyr::across(dplyr::starts_with("npp"), function(.x) .x/1000), npp = paste0(round(npp_mean, 2), " \\pm ", round(npp_sd, 2))) |> dplyr::pull(npp)`) or other studies [@Wieder.2016; @Wieder.2019]. It is likely that samples with large proportion of one species (group) have been formed during periods where this species (group) had comparatively large NPP because otherwise it could not have become dominant. More accurate estimates can be obtained when bulk density is measured and not predicted from MIRS, as we did here.  
It is likely that at least model `r dd_model_names(1, dd_model_info)` underestimates the degree of decomposition for many of these peat samples (because they have a small N content and probably average degree of decomposition, Fig. \@ref(fig:dd-plot-8)) and that model `r dd_model_names(3, dd_model_info)` overestimates the degree of decomposition for the more decomposed layers, meaning that the degree of decomposition likely is in-between the estimates of all three models. This could mean that hummock *Sphagnum* species can have a small mass loss even in peat thousands of years old.


## Estimating differences of litter-specific decomposition rates and the slow-down of decomposition according to the Holocene Peatland Model {#dd-discussion-analysis-of-long-term-decomposition}

The suggested decomposition indicator may also be useful to analyze decomposition rates under natural conditions and for time periods much longer than litterbag experiments. As for the reconstruction of NPP, naive approaches are not suitable because for each sample, we can only measure the state at one specific time point, but measurements of identical initial litter decomposed from the same time point on would be required to analyze data from peat cores in the same way as litterbag experiments. However, when environmental factors scale decomposition rates in the same way for different litter types, as assumed by decomposition modules of many peatland models, including the decomposition module in the Holocene Peatland Model [@Frolking.2001; @Frolking.2010], and if the degree of decomposition of two litter types from the same peat layer can be measured (for example with a component-specific analysis), it is possible to estimate the difference (or ratio) of the decomposition rates of the litter types (supporting section \@ref(si-dd-rate-differences-2)). This could be a useful alternative to direct litterbag experiments because it avoids possible biases in decomposition rate estimates in litterbag experiments due to sample preprocessing [@Barlocher.1997; @Koronatova.2010a; @Teickner.2025], and it may inrease the signal-to-noise ratio because litter type-specific differences may be better detectable over longer time periods. Moreover, analyzing peat samples with $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ may be a faster alternative to litterbag experiments which may allow to obtain more precise average estimates for decomposition rates than with litterbag experiments.  
An influential parameter in the Holocene Peatland Model is the rate at which decomposition slows down the more of the initial mass is lost ($\alpha$) [@Frolking.2010]. This parameter cannot be precisely estimated from peat cores or litterbag experiments [@Frolking.2001; @Teickner.2025] because they are too short to precisely estimate $\alpha$. When decomposition happens according to the decomposition module of the Holocene Peatland Model and litter-type specific decomposition rates under optimal conditions (conditions that maximize decomposition rates) are known, component-specific estimates for the degree of decomposition depend only on $\alpha$ (section \@ref(si-dd-rate-differences-2)). This approach may therefore be useful to estimate $\alpha$ from peat layers.

# Conclusions

We developed and evaluated a novel decomposition indicator, the degree of decomposition measured in litterbag experiments predicted from MIRS ($\gamma_\text{MIRS}$). To our knowledge, besides $\gamma_\text{ARM}$, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is the only decomposition indicator that measures the degree of decomposition on an absolute scale. In contrast to $\gamma_\text{ARM}$, no assumptions on initial states have to be made and the degree of decomposition of undecomposed litter can be predicted accurately for many diverse litter types, which reduces errors when estimating the degree of decomposition with $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ compared to $\gamma_\text{ARM}$. Compared to other commonly used qualitative decomposition indicators (C/N, H/C, O/C, $\delta^{13}$C, $\delta^{15}$N, HI$_{1630/1090}$, $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$, and NOSC), $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is biased much less by differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter. Compared to MIRS-humification indices, it is biased less by minerals. This makes $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ particularly useful for the interpretation of peat cores, reconstruction of past NPP, and improvement of peatland models. Further research is useful to improve our models to predict $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$. In particular, it is useful to include more diverse litter types in the training and test data, and to better test the influence of minerals and differences in protein contents on $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$.  
We identified a limitation of most existing decomposition indicators, and all decomposition indicators analyzed here except $\gamma_\text{ARM}$: the decomposition indicators measure a signal that changes non-linearly when novel components are added to a sample because more decomposed samples contribute less to the signal than less decomposed samples, relative to their initial mass. For samples consisting of multiple components (e.g., litter types), the degree of decomposition will therefore be underestimated by bulk measurements. Our analysis suggests that even if the decomposition indicator can predict the degree of decomposition of each component perfectly, this bias can exceed 50% for samples with multiple components. In combination with our result that most existing decomposition indicators confound differences in initial litter chemistry with decomposition, this makes it unlikely that individual chemical or physical peat properties can be used to accurately estimate the degree of decomposition of peat samples. We argue that this bias has not been noticed in previous studies because there have been few efforts to measurements of the degree of decomposition from litterbag experiments.  
Since $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ estimates the degree of decomposition for individual litter types, it may be possible to avoid this bias with a component-specific analysis, where $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is estimated for each litter type in a peat sample. We discuss that this offers opportunities to analyze decomposition processes over longer time periods than is currently possible with litterbag experiments because decomposition can be traced throughout peat cores. We illustrated that this strategy may be useful to estimate litter type-specific decomposition rates and the slow-down of decomposition rates over time. Since peatland models can simulate how $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is biased in multi-component peat samples, bulk $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ estimates are suitable to improve peatland models. Even more, our analyses suggest that under some conditions underestimation of the degree of decomposition of peat samples or dominant components by bulk $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ estimates is small. We used this to estimate the degree of decomposition of several *Sphagnum*-dominated peat samples and reconstruct their NPP, which was previously only possible with process models.  
That $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is testable against litterbag experiments and therefore can be used to identify and analyze existing error sources is an improvement over existing decomposition indicators because it allows to continuously improve models to estimate $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$. We expect that the suggested decomposition indicator is a suitable replacement for currently used decomposition indicators and that it is useful to reconstruct past NPP and improve peatland models, especially when combined with a component-specific analysis of peat samples. 








<!--The suggested decomposition indicator --- the degree of decomposition predicted from mid infrared spectra, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ --- has several advantages over existing decomposition indicators: It is a direct estimate for the degree of decomposition of litter types, only requires transmission mid infrared measurements, and is independently testable against litterbag experiments. We illustrated that other decomposition indicators (C/N, humification indices, $\delta^{13}$C, $\delta^{15}$N, O/C, H/C, NOSC, and $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$) confound differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter between species with decomposition mass losses and we hypothesize that many of them can vary for undecomposed litter as much as they vary due to decomposition. abstract: |
  The degree of decomposition of peat ($\gamma$) is useful to understand peatland degradation, past peat accumulation patterns, to reconstruct past net primary production (NPP), and to improve peatland models. To date, only the ash residue method allows to estimate $\gamma$ on an absolute scale, but has large errors; other decomposition indicators measure only qualitative differences of $\gamma$, are confounded by differences in the chemistry between litter types or by differences in mineral contents. We suggest prediction of $\gamma$ measured in litterbag experiments from mid infrared spectra (MIRS) as novel decomposition indicator, $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$. Moreover, we identify and analyze a previously neglected error source of most decomposition indicators which can cause underestimation of $\gamma$ by more than 50% and elaborate strategies to avoid this error source to reconstruct past *Sphagnum* NPP from peat samples with $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$.     
  An evaluation of existing decomposition indicators (C/N, H/C, O/C, $\delta^{13}$C, $\delta^{15}$N, humification indices, Gibbs free energy of formation, and nominal oxidation state of C) indicates that these decomposition indicators are confounded by differences in the chemistry of undecomposed litter. Evaluation of prediction models for $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ indicates that it can predict $\gamma$ for several litter types with small prediction errors (ca. 10%) and is biased much less by differences in initial litter chemistry. Tests with peat cores indicate that $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ can identify peat layers degraded by drainage and less decomposed peat layers with fast *Sphagnum* growth. Simulations are used to develop strategies how $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ can be used to improve process models, reconstruct past NPP despite the identified bias, and use peat cores to estimate decomposition model parameters. NPP of *Sphagnum* species during the Holocene reconstructed from peat cores agree with NPP ranges given in the literature. These properties and applications make $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ useful for the interpretation of peat cores, reconstruction of past NPP, and improvement of peatland models. That $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ is testable against litterbag experiments and therefore can be used to identify and analyze existing error sources is an improvement over existing decomposition indicators; this allows to continuously improve the models to estimate $\gamma_\text{MIRS}$ with more diverse litter types and samples with varying mineral contents.

<!--Currently, no method exists to directly measure the degree of decomposition of peat, but such measurements are useful to assess how degraded a peatland is, to reconstruct past net primary production, and to improve reconstruction of past environmental conditions and mass fluxes with peatland models. --><!--We suggest a decomposition indicator that directly estimates the degree of decomposition from mid infrared spectra, using prediction models that were computed with litterbag data where the degree of decomposition can be directly measured. By design, the suggested decomposition indicator is linearly related to the degree of decomposition, tested and testable against litterbag data, confounds, compared to commonly used decomposition indicators (C/N, H/C, O/C, $\delta^{13}$C, $\delta^{15}$N, humification indices, $\Delta$G$_\text{f}^0$, and NOSC), differences in initial litter chemistry with decomposition less, does not misinterpret the degree of decomposition for samples with large mineral contents or for samples with differences in protein contents (unlike humification indices), and is relatively easy to measure. Despite these advantages, predictions of our models probably have comparatively large errors for litter types not included in the training data, more decomposed samples, and samples with larger mineral contents, because we used a heterogeneous and comparatively small dataset, and the models extrapolate for many peat samples. The average degree of decomposition may be used to reconstruct past NPP from peat layer masses, but we show that simply dividing remaining masses by one minus the degree of decomposition underestimates initial layer masses when the sample consists of components with different degree of decomposition. Such biases may be avoided by process models or component-specific estimates for the degree of decomposition. Under some conditions, the simple approach has small bias, and we use it to reconstruct average NPP for several *Sphagnum* species at three sites during some periods of the Holocene. We expect that the suggested decomposition indicator, or an improved version of it, is a suitable replacement for currently used decomposition indicators.--><!-- and that it will be useful to reconstruct past NPP and distinguish between environmental conditions that lead to similar net peat accumulation but with different water table depths and process rates in peatland models.-->
